results.title: The Communal sense of modesty = Il commune senso del pudore
results.creator_credit: Rizzoli Film, Fausto Saraceni and Alberto Sordi
results.brief_description: Four humorous vignettes starring and directed by top Italian comic actor Alberto Sordi which take place on the same day. The first tells of a conservative married couple in search of a movie theatre which take place on the same day. The second is about life in a successful magazine company. The third deals with the increasing popularity of sex magazines in Italy. The fourth and final story tells of a ‘primadonna’ actress constantly throwing tantrums in a film studio. In Italian language with no English subtitles.

results.title: The Commonwealth
results.creator_credit: Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films and Joy Batchelor
results.brief_description: An animated film describing the structure of the Commonwealth of Nations, touching on co-operation in trade, industry and education and showing the common heritage of British ideas and institutions uniting peoples of diverse cultures. Commentary by Peter Haigh.

results.title: The Common cold
results.creator_credit: Informedia Productions (US), Canawest Films and Kelly Duncan
results.brief_description: Examines the worth or worthlessness of vaccines, antibiotics, vitamin C and other remedies for the common cold. Emphasises body resistance as the best protection. The structure and function of the virus which causes the cold is explained.

results.title: The Common cold
results.brief_description: Illustrates the facts known about the common cold, its care, and secondary infections that may grow out of it. Tells the story of a boy who contracts a cold and visits his doctor for treatment and advice. Reveals by means of the doctor’s illustrated explanation, why the common cold is serious and how it should be treated.

results.title: The Commissar = Kimissar
results.brief_description: Based on the novel “In the town of Berdichev” by Vassily Grossman. In the Ukraine in 1920 during the Russian Civil War, a weary commissar (political officer) finds that she is pregnant. The home of a poor Jewish tinker and his family is requisitioned for her confinement. Mutual suspicion gives way to warmer emotions. The commissar and her new baby become part of his extended family. With flashbacks, a surrealistic dream sequence and grim fantasy, the simple story is given a wider perspective as a meditation on Jewish suffering.

results.title: The Commandos
results.creator_credit: Cine Service, Australia. Royal Air Force. Films Advisory Bureau and Geoffrey Thompson
results.brief_description: Shows the tough training which makes CMF commandos: unarmed defence, cross-country fitness tests, cliff-climbing, parachute-jumping, canoeing and swimming. Includes an exercise in which commandos attach an “enemy strong-point” by sea and air.

results.title: The Coming of darkness
results.brief_description: Seventh in a series of nine animated films on the history of Western Civilization. Discusses the two world wars and the events in Germany, Italy, China, Japan and Russia which were contributing factors. Contends that both were capitalist wars in which workers were fighting workers. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: The Comic Strip 2: Mr Jolly Lives Next Door/Consuela
results.brief_description: Mr Jolly Lives Next Door - The inappropriately named hit man “Mr Jolly” (Peter Cook) rents an office space next door to the alcoholic incompetents Rik and Ade (Rik Mayall and Adrian Edmondson), proprietors of “Dreamytimer Escorts”, London’s seediest escort service. Through a catalogue of mistakes and misunderstandings the deranged Mr Lovebucket (Peter Richardson), purveyor of wines and spirits to most London off-licences, he finds he has paid Rik and Ade 3,000 pounds to “take out Nicholas Parsons”. Murderous implications arise behind Mr Lovebucket’s back. “Consuelo” - John (Adrian Edmondson) returns to his ancestral home, “Brownstokes” with a pretty new wife, Jessica (Jennifer Saunders).

results.title: The Comic Strip 1: Eddie Monsoon/Didn't You Kill My Brother
results.brief_description: Eddie Monsoon - written by Adrian Edmondson - star of “The Young Ones”, is a mock documentary about a South African TV host who’s a lush - and very violent. He’s a slightly quieter version of Vivian from the “Young Ones”, but set in the real world. The film includes excerpts from Monsoon’s under- standably few TV appearances, and interviews with his ex-wife (played by Jennifer Saunders of Saunders and French) and ex-manager (played by Peter Richardson). “Didn’t you kill my Brother” - written by Alexei Sayle, Pauline Melville and David Stafford. It tells the story of twin criminal brothers, Carl and Moss Sterling (both played by Sayle). After five years in prison, Carl emerges with 428 academic qualifications, a gentle manner and a Liverpool accent. He sets up a legitimate bicycle-making business at the local youth centre. Carl’s brother Sterling is meanwhile running a racket where the kids steal every bicycle in sight so that he can respray and resell them. Eventually the brothers clash, with fatal results. Rated: PG

results.title: The Comic Spirit (TEFC)
results.brief_description: A look at the different elements of comedy, performed and workshopped by the New Shakespeare Company from the Open Air Theatre in Regent’s Park. Shows sequences from modern comedy routines and relates these ideas of the comic genre to scenes from a number of Shakespearian comedies.
